Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: The coordinator emailed a brief suggestion about organizing supplies a different way if time allows.
Story: My phone buzzed with a message from my mom just as I was sorting boxes at the community center. She wanted to know how my day was going and if I’d eaten lunch yet. I knew she expected a quick reply, maybe even a photo of my meal, like I usually sent her every afternoon. At the same time, I remembered the volunteer coordinator’s email from this morning—she’d suggested reorganizing the supply shelves if I had extra time. I glanced at the clock. If I stopped now to text my mom, I’d lose my momentum and might not finish the new organization system before my shift ended. But if I ignored her message, she’d worry, maybe even call, and I’d feel guilty for breaking our daily routine. I could almost hear her voice in my head, asking if everything was okay. My hands hovered over my phone, torn between the comfort of reassuring my mom and the responsibility of following through on my volunteer duties. The pressure of both expectations pressed in on me, and I hesitated, caught between being a good son and a reliable volunteer.
